title: 108_hr904
content: The Act is titled the "United States Life-Saving Service Heritage Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that the United States Life-Saving Service stations, staffed by brave volunteers and professionals, are of architectural significance but are threatened by coastal environments and neglect. The heroic actions of personnel deserve greater recognition. The United States Life-Saving Service stations, staffed by brave volunteers and professionals, deserve greater recognition and preservation. This Act aims to establish a program to inventory, evaluate, document, and assist in preserving these historic stations. The United States Life-Saving Service Station Preservation Program is established under SEC. 3. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a program to inventory, evaluate, document, and assist in preserving surviving United States Life-Saving Service stations. This includes surveying coastal regions, documenting designs of structures and boats, and evaluating the historic significance of the stations. The Secretary of the Interior will assess historic lifesaving stations for significance and condition, recommend stations for National Historic Landmark designation, and provide technical assistance and educational materials for preservation efforts. The Secretary of the Interior provides assistance for shipwrecked mariners by offering information on the history of lifesaving services, technical descriptions of lifesaving equipment, guidance for listing historic stations, and grants for preservation efforts. The Federal government provides financial assistance for the preservation of historic lifesaving stations, with a maximum cost share of 75 percent. Definitions include what constitutes a historic lifesaving station and the role of the Secretary of the Interior in overseeing the National Maritime Initiative. Authorization of appropriations is granted to the Secretary for this purpose. The Secretary is appropriated $5,000,000 annually for grants under subsection (d) and $500,000 for other provisions from 2004 to 2008.
